review_title: A career for the right people!  Valued employees, and opportunity for advancement!
job_title: Admissions/Recruiting Coordinator in Campina Grande, Paraíba
pros: The culture at Heritage is one in which employees are valued and given the opportunity for more if they work hard.  Although there is a lot of structure, which most people mistake for micromanagement when it is in fact regulatory requirements, Heritage invests in its employees for the future.  Executive leadership targets up and coming employees, especially in Admissions, due to the fact that they learn structure and regulations as a part of their time learning the business.  The recruiting aspect along with learning time-management and organizational skills makes Admissions employees ideal for advancement opportunities.  The envrionment, however, is not for everyone.  The state and federal governments, along with accreditation guidelines, make the admissions department a managed place.  Scripts ensure compliance with regulations, many mistake the use of scripts as "managment control", when in fact there are greater reasons.  Admissions managers sit in on student calls and meetings to ensure Admissions employees are giving correct information to students; if the information is incorrect, a regulation could be compromised.  So, in short, current future employees won't have to look very far to see executive leadership that started as an Admissions Coordinator within a school.  I assure you, the grass is not greener.  Herirtage is an amazing place to work where hard-work is noticed and valued.
cons: Heavy regulation.  This has nothing to do with Heritage, and more to do with the compliance that must be achieved through strict process.

pros: I can understand why some of the low reviews exist for Heritage. There has been a tremendous amount of change. I also have an appreciation for what Heritage College is trying to accomplish. When I compare my first day at work to now, the change is nothing short of compelling. The Heritage I started at a couple years ago had no direction and was just going through the motions of survival. Now I see that we are starting to get a clear direction on where we need to focus on helping our students achieve success. For the first time in a while, I understand my purpose, and what I need to accomplish when I arrive at work. I know the Heritage world doesn't evolve around me but thank you for including me on your team. Is Heritage perfect? Far from it but I am very appreciative of the direction they are starting to take.
cons: If you don't do well with change, this place probably isn't for you. I have been employed at other schools and one thing I can say about Heritage is that they do not have patience for laziness or bad habits that others bring from other schools. If change isn't for you and learning new things doesn't excite you, I would stay away from here because this place is probably not a fit.

review_title: Changing Lives and Improving My Community
job_title: Director of Student Records in Denver, CO
pros:
I've been with Heritage for over 15 years. The company began in the neighborhood and community that I grew up in. At that time the most of the community was comprised of minorities with a high school education level at best. It was the history and pattern of the community at that time to hopefully graduate high school or earn a GED, then join the work force at minimum wage and hope to provide for a family and build a future based off of that alone. Even most of the community elders were still working labor intensive jobs earning mediocre pay when most of them should have been nearing retirement. Not many finished high school, and even less were fortunate enough to afford a college education. 
Although in the early years Heritage remained small, the impact it had on the community was a huge one! Throughout the last 15 years I have watched so many people from my very neighborhood earn degrees and have actual careers rather than just jobs. Even when history and odds were working against them Heritage opened the door to possibilities that didn't exist for them in the past. While 15 years later both the neighborhood and the community have changed completely, so has the pattern of life and more important so has it's history. 
Working for Heritage has been one of the most amazing and fulfilling experiences of my life. I am so proud to be part of an organization that truly does change lives, mine included.
cons: Being grouped by society as just another "career college". I believe that the experience, the people and the education our graduates walk away with put Heritage levels above the "career college" stereotype.

review_title: An unethical, unprofessional "college" - Stay away if you have a brain, integrity, or an ethical code
pros: There are no pros to working here At All.
cons:
I have never had to work in an environment where my job was taking advantage of needy people in the most disgusting way possible--and that is by taking advantage of their desire to improve their lives through education.
Here are just a few examples of Heritage's unethical model:

1. Hound anyone who has ever contacted Heritage (either directly, or by mistake) THREE times a day. This includes using a cell phone with different numbers in the hopes that they won't recognize the number and will pick up. Even if the person hangs up on you, you are instructed to continue calling...

2. Handle direct questions, such as "how much does it cost, or what is the program length" with the most evasive answers possible. I was instructed to never give out any information and to find a way to "take control" of the call and get them to give you answers about their life and why they want this. IF they mention a program Heritage doesn't offer (music, being a barber) you are still instructed to try to get them to come in for a "required information session." 

3. Same-day appointments are gold to this company, as they are with any sales... Get them while they are hot! Unfortunately, Heritage doesn't think there is any way someone could be serious about their education if they are not ready to drop whatever they are doing to come in for the "required information session." After you get off these phone calls, you will be chastised about why you didn't do enough to "motivate" them.

The entire process is paternalism at its worst. The costs of the programs are asinine and most students realize this after doing more research and choose to go somewhere else where they won’t be saddled in $20000-$30000 of debt for a job that might only pay them $8 an hour. Of course, if the admissions rep doesn’t find a way to convince that student to choose Heritage, you have failed.

I originally thought this job would be helping people to change their lives, but I found myself engaged in the sales job from hell—working with and for people with no integrity or respect. This job is an embarrassment to my resume and I can’t believe I even worked at a place who would treat people like this. Any time I had any questions about the rationale for the process I was basically informed to just do what I was told. If you have a brain, or an ethical code, or integrity, do not work here. The only people that can survive in this company are people who either have no idea of the recruitment process used, idiots who can’t think for themselves, or people without basic respect for other humans.
